Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC: Collaborative Research: Center for Spatiotemporal Thinking Computing and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
PROGRAM DIRECTOR'S RECOMMENDATION
1338925 George Mason University; Chaowei Yang
1338914 Harvard University; Peter Bol
1338902 University of California-Santa Barbara; Keith Clarke

George Mason University (GMU) as the lead institution, Harvard University (HU), and the University of California Santa Barbara (UCSB) are proposing to establish a center for spatiotemporal thinking, computing and applications.

The proposal seeks to establish an I/UCRC for spatiotemporal thinking, computing and applications as a collaborative platform among industry, university, government agencies, and other organizations to advance this domain of knowledge. The proposed center will be established based upon the previous successes at each of the three sites including: a) the Center for Intelligent Spatial Computing (CISC) at GMU for spatiotemporal computing/software development; b) the Center for Spatial Studies (CSS) at UCSB for spatial thinking and analyses; and c) the Center for Geographic Analysis (CGA) at Harvard for spatiotemporal applications.

The mission of the new Center would be to integrate these technologies into a comprehensive spatiotemporal theory and applications. Research results and success stories will be disseminated through publications in relevant spatiotemporal venues as well as among the center member sites for adoption and outreach. The PIs plan to use their established relationship with leading organizations to broadcast the research results and recruit new members through the organization channels. The PIs plan to develop new curriculum within existing degree programs at the three sites, and to continue their diversity traditions to include minorities and other underrepresented groups in center activities

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The  I/UCRC: Collaborative Research: Center for Spatiotemporal Thinking Computing and Applications during Phase 1 had three sites: George Mason University, Harvard University and the University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB). The UCSB site was not funded for Phase 2 of the center, with UCSB leaving the two other universities and the administration functions of the center. UCSB projects were funded from multiple sources during phase 1, including USGS, NASA, Seimens and Microsoft. A major accomplishment was the application of linked data principles to queries about the National Map, allowing more far ranging and flexible information extraction from a major national dataset. Over phase 1, graduate students were supported for PhD. work, peer reviewed papers were created and published, and annual meetings on Spatiotemporal computing hosted at the annual American Association of Geographers meetings. Two International conferences on Spatiotemporal computing were organized and a special issue of the International Journal of Geographical Information Science edited, including a review paper on research prospects for spatiotemporal computing. Two summer workshops on spatiotemporal computing were held at UCSB with funds from the Zhejiang Administration of Surveying Mapping and Geoinformation in China. A total of five Research Experience for Undergraduates students received summer funds and travel to national conferences under this award.


Last Modified: 12/12/2019
Modified by: Keith C Clarke
